text: hello in this video I will show you how
to generate and use Amazon inspector
s-bomb exports
first let's understand what is a s-bomb
and why should you care
esbom stands for software bill of
materials it contains machine readable
nested inventory of all open source and
third-party software components of your
code base and its supply chain
s-bombs can be used to understand the
software you can zoom and vulnerability
is associated with any dependencies
think about the food you eat assume
you're allergic to strawberries so you
need to know the ingredients of the food
to understand if there are any
strawberries used in the preparation
if you know the produces strawberry then
it's obvious you should not be eating it
however if you're eating chocolate
coated fruit you need to know the fruit
inside the chocolate is a strawberry so
you do not consume it
next say you're eating an ice cream
sundae you would want to check all the
ingredients of the sundae including all
the sub ingredients the sundae could
have chocolate brownie with vanilla m m
ice cream that has mixed animal flavors
including strawberry m m
in order to truly understand if
strawberries were used anywhere in the
supply chain you may need to know the
details about all ingredients how they
were prepared and even where they are
sourced from to see if there could be
contaminants
and s-bomb gives you such details about
the software and Hardware inventory plot
direct or transitive dependency graphs
it can also help you identify known
vulnerabilities verify Integrity of
packages origin of software components
and also support audit use cases
Amazon inspector provides s-bombs for
individual or groups of resources
monitored by inspector in your
environment
these can be exported into an Amazon S3
bucket inspector supports exporting
s-bombs in Cyclone DX and spdx formats
both these formats are leading industry
standards for s-bombs
s-bombs exported from inspector can help
you gain visibility into your software
supply chain you can Garner information
such as the most commonly used packages
and Associated vulnerabilities across
your organization
once exported to S3 you can use Athena
or quicksite to run queries on these
reports
now let's look at how you can generate
an s-bomb from inspector
if you want to export the s-bomb for
multiple accounts in your AWS
organization you will need to generate
the s-bomb from your inspector delegated
administrator account
in this scenario I am logged into my
delegated admin account
you will first need to configure the S3
bucket and the AWS KMS key that
inspector is allowed to use to export
configurations and permissions needed
for the S3 bucket and KMS can be found
in the inspector documentation
if you have previously configured ns3
bucket and AWS KMS key for findings
export you can use the same bucket and
key for a spawn export as well
let's say you want to identify top
vulnerabilities affecting your workloads
and you want to search through the
primary software components as well as
the dependencies
you can use the yes bomb for this use
case
first you'll need to generate the s-bomb
in the inspector console choose export
as bonds
here you can either export reports from
all active resources or subset of
resources using filters
next select the format xpdx or Cyclone
DX
choose this S3 bucket destination for
export
then select the KMS key
and then click export
you will see the status bar indicating
the export is in progress
once complete the status will change to
Green
let's go look at our export in S3
inspector will create an s-bomb file for
each active resource that inspector is
monitoring since we do not use any
filter inspector will partition the
s-bombs by account ID and resource type
as you can see here I have s-bombs here
for ec2 instances container images and
Lambda functions
and finally you can see there's a s-bomb
for each resource ID
let's open nsbon
I will paste the contents in a Json
prettifier to view the report with
indentation
there you go now you can see the
contents of the s-bomb
since this is Cyclone DX format you can
see the version number metadata such as
the timestamp when the s-bomb was
generated
operating system information
properties applicable to the
organization using the s-spomb which in
case of AWS would be account ID resource
type Arn Etc
the components include the inventory the
first party and the third party software
packages and dependencies in those
resources
you can also see the package URL of
pearl which includes the name of the
package version number subpath Etc
as you can see the list is long since
this is an ec2 instance it includes the
OS packages as well as the programming
language packages
now if you scroll all the way towards
the button you can see the
vulnerabilities associated with software
components listed here as well
let's take a quick look at the xbdx
version
I already have a s-bomb exported in spdx
as you can see

similar information as compared to
Cyclone DX
now that the is-bomb is generated we
will use Athena to identify the top
vulnerabilities in the workload
in this demo I've already set up a glue
crawler for schema generation and then
created a table from it
to learn more about the glue crawler
setup visit this link
in this query I'm listing the top 10
items in the table you can see the
contents are similar to The Raw s-bomb
we saw a few minutes ago
while the rest of the demo I will be
querying the s-bombs in the Cyclone DX
format
you can use similar queries for spdx as
well
now let's create a report to identify
the top 10 models for resources in the
s-bomb
you can then use these cve IDs to list
the individual components affected by
the cves
let's look at another query that can be
used to identify top operating systems
along with resource types and their
accounts
say you want to identify the counts of
packages that are used in the workloads
this next query can help you with it
this information can then be used for
risk assessments and Remediation
prioritization
finally let's say you have a package
that has a critical zero day
vulnerability and you need to know if
the package is used in the workload as a
primary package or a dependency you can
use this query to identify the existence
of this package in your application
in this example I am searching for
ncurses package
the results show the account number the
resource type and the count for this
package
once you identify where these packages
exist you can begin your volumed
remediation efforts
you can reproduce the s-bombs in your
accounts by following inspectors as bomb
export documentation
you can use the console or generate the
s-bomb programmatically using the create
s-bomb export API operation
in this video we learned about s-bomb
its use cases and how to generate it
using Amazon inspector for supported
resources and then querying it using
